item.title: Covid-19: Continue using AstraZeneca vaccine, says WHO
item.description: It says there is no evidence of a link to blood clots, as major EU countries pause use of the vaccine.

item.title: Covid-19: Protest warning, and more EU countries halt Oxford jabs
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday evening.

item.title: Sarah Everard killing: Police search Sandwich town centre
item.description: Police investigating the death of the 33-year-old cordon off part of Sandwich, Kent.

item.title: Ministers frustrated with PM's 'mistakes' ahead of Covid second wave
item.description: Senior figures tell the BBC Boris Johnson should have been tougher in the autumn to prevent more deaths.

item.title: Covid-19: Portugal removed from England's travel ban list
item.description: Ethiopia, Oman, Somalia and Qatar will be added when changes come into force at 04:00 GMT on Friday.

item.title: Oscars nominations 2021: Brits, diversity and female directors rewarded
item.description: It is also a record year for diversity in the acting nominations and for female directors.

item.title: Covid: UK vaccination surge expected in coming days
item.description: All over 50s could be vaccinated ahead of schedule, thanks to good supplies, say experts.

item.title: Thorntons: Chocolate maker to close all shops putting 600 jobs at risk
item.description: The chain blames High Street conditions for its decision to shut 61 shops, putting 603 jobs at risk.

item.title: Covid contracts: Dog food vendor is likely to have got Â£1m for PPE deals
item.description: Zoe Ley brokered deals with a Hong Kong firm to supply goggles and gowns to UK health officials.

item.title: Anthony Joshua v Tyson Fury moves a step closer as Eddie Hearn says two-fight deal agreed
item.description: Anthony Joshua and Tyson Fury's world heavyweight title showdown moves a step closer with Joshua's promoter Eddie Hearn saying a two-fight deal has been signed.

item.title: Brexit: EU to begin legal action over alleged NI Protocol breach
item.description: PM Boris Johnson says the UK's actions "temporary and technical measures that we think are very sensible".

item.title: Yo-Yo Ma: World-famous cellist's impromptu vaccine centre concert
item.description: Yo-Yo Ma performs in a waiting room after receiving his second dose of Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: Grammy Awards 2021: Red carpet in pictures
item.description: The stars swapped their lockdown outfits for glad rags on "music's biggest night".

item.title: Covid: Hairdressers reopen in Wales as lockdown eases
item.description: One salon owners says some of her clients burst into tears on being told they were reopening.

item.title: Australia March 4 Justice: Thousands march against sexual assault
item.description: Tens of thousands of people across Australia protested against abuse and harassment.

item.title: Redcar rescue: Man who pulled girl from sea 'acted on instinct'
item.description: Cleveland Police said those that tried to help the 10-year-old girl were "heroes".

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I lost my job and launched a pop-up food business'
item.description: Online takeaway deliveries have soared in the pandemic and some firms are stronger for making them.

item.title: Delivery driver with car full of parcels 'unable to see road'
item.description: The courier could barely see out of the "overloaded" vehicle, say police who stopped it in Sheffield.

item.title: Nagorno-Karabakh: A home regained and a home lost in war
item.description: How lives on both sides of the divide in Nagorno-Karabakh were changed by the last year's fighting.

item.title: Avatar reclaims title as highest-grossing film
item.description: Disney said the blockbuster film regained top spot over the weekend knocking off Avengers: End Game.

item.title: Photos from Australia: Capturing 'flash rips' and 'the edge of the world'
item.description: Dene Bingham photographs dangerous seas and wild places from a remote coast in Western Australia.

item.title: Tigray crisis: Why Sudan is a âsecond homeâ to Ethiopian refugees
item.description: More than 60,000 people have fled the conflict in Ethiopiaâs Tigray region to seek refuge in Sudan.

item.title: Grammys 2021: Five weird and wonderful moments
item.description: Harry Styles, Dua Lipa and Megan Thee Stallion all put on a spectacle. But who are Silk Sonic?

item.title: Sarah Everard vigil: 'All I wanted was to stand with other women'
item.description: Why hundreds of women felt compelled to take part in the vigil for Sarah Everard - despite being told it was cancelled.

item.title: What is the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill and how will it change protests?
item.description: Public protests have pushed the government's controversial new police bill into the spotlight.

item.title: Review: The Grammy Awards reflect a year of solitude and protest
item.description: Quarantine songs and Black Lives Matter anthems defined this year's music awards.

item.title: Discovering WW1 tunnel of death hidden in France for a century
item.description: The bodies of 270 German soldiers have lain hidden since they were buried alive by a French bombardment.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Has Covid changed hospitals for the better?
item.description: Dr John Wright of Bradford Royal Infirmary says some changes made as a result of the pandemic are here to stay.

item.title: We asked for your first Covid text messages. These are your stories
item.description: The US didnât shut down until late March, but Americans were talking about the virus before that.

item.title: 'Interest in e-sports will only grow and grow'
item.description: The global e-sports sector is expected to see revenues of more than $1bn in 2021.

item.title: India's interfaith couples on edge after new law
item.description: A Hindu-Muslim couple, who dated secretly for 13 years, are now facing a fresh obstacle: the government.

item.title: Viewpoint: France's President Macron doesn't get the impact of colonialism on Algeria
item.description: The French president may not be able to repair relations with Algerians, argues writer Maher Mezahi.

item.title: England's remaining three T20s against India to be behind closed doors
item.description: England's remaining three Twenty20 internationals against India in Ahmedabad will be played behind closed doors because of rising coronavirus cases in the state of Gujarat.

item.title: Ireland's Ringrose and Ryan out of England game
item.description: Lock James Ryan and centre Garry Ringrose are ruled out of Ireland's final Six Nations match against England on Saturday.

item.title: Ramsey included as Allen returns for Wales qualifiers
item.description: Juventus' Aaron Ramsey is named in Wales' squad for this month's World Cup qualifiers despite being an injury doubt, while Joe Allen returns.

item.title: Smith Rowe and Hudson-Odoi named in strong England U21 Euros squad
item.description: Mason Greenwood, Callum Hudson-Odoi & Emile Smith Rowe named in a strong England squad for next week's Uefa U21 Euro finals group stage.

item.title: Ex-England wicketkeeper Taylor joins Sussex coaching staff
item.description: Former England wicketkeeper Sarah Taylor is to join Sussex's coaching staff.

item.title: Match of the Day 2: Watch Erik Lamela's 'rabona' goal for Tottenham Hotspur against Arsenal
item.description: Match of the Day 2 pundits Martin Keown and Jermaine Jenas analyse Erik Lamela's incredible 'rabona' finish against Arsenal.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 24 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: MPs have said the government's test-and-trace system is too expensive and hasn't helped fight the pandemic.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: How do we know Covid vaccines are safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?

item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What are the new rules for schools?
item.description: All students in England can now return to classrooms, but how will Covid testing work?

item.description: There are multiple coronavirus vaccines being rolled out in countries across the UK and around the world. What happens if you don't want it?

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK. So when might you get one?

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus, schools and children - what are the risks?
item.description: How much do children contribute to the spread of Covid?

item.title: The art dealer, the Â£10m Benin Bronze and the Holocaust
item.description: Western museums are under pressure to return looted treasure, but what of those in private collections?
